item.description: Wesley Snipes fired Italian PA Fabrizia Rubicola on the set of Cornuto, an Italian “spaghetti” thriller pitting Snipes, clad only in his bathrobe and slippers, in a race against time to prove he isn’t a cuckold. item.title: Fact #541
item.description: Zimbabwean string cheese magnate and Rappelli’s dwarf Elon Musk dedicated the launching of his first cave submarine, the E.M. Intrepidus, to the memory of Bartleby the Scrivener Snipes, Wesley Snipes’ second known child with Vietnamese pit bull trainer Linda Ng.

item.title: Fact #540
item.description: In 1997, Wesley Snipes and veteran BET showrunner Lief Dardanelles debuted an all-black spinoff of the popular TV series Love Boat called Tug Boat Mack, starring Ossie Davis as Mack, a cantankerous but well-meaning tug boat captain, and Omar Epps as “the Rascal”. item.title: Fact #539
item.description: Wesley Snipes couldn’t somersault. For most of his martial arts scenes in the 1990s, Snipes’ shomer Martin Pinkus, a Hasidic Jew from Lakewood, New Jersey, performed the forward rolls and tumbling.

item.title: Fact #538
item.description: The music for Ruggiero Bosk’s 1999 adaptation of Wesley Snipes’ one-act play The Leopard Tamer was actually written by Wesley Snipes. It wasn’t until 2006 that the original score for drum brush and vibraslap was adapted for the unreleased O.J. Simpson music video LA Interstate.

item.title: Fact #537
item.description: While in prison, Wesley Snipes starred alongside fellow convict Romeo Poe in Honolulu Silence, a disaster film that pits Snipes against a minor volcano set to erupt and destroy the chief of police’s rural wedding.

item.title: Fact #536
item.description: In a r/WhoWouldWin subreditt AMA hosted by stuntman Clay Donahue Fontenot, eighty-four percent of reditters said they were unaware that Wesley Snipes was a midget. item.title: Fact #535
item.description: The idea to make Randall “Tex” Cobb’s character Slow Boy suffer from an unspecified laughing disorder in 1992’s Dome City was Wesley Snipes’.

item.title: Fact #534
item.description: In 1989, Wesley Snipes and celebrity florist DeFews Geary lost a five-year court battle to trademark the phrase “wipe on wipe off.” Their eponymous modular carwash/pizza parlor in Hollywood’s Little Armenia was subsequently shuttered by court order.

item.description: In 2005, Wesley Snipes pitched a cigar abuse comedy to writer and chimpanzee rights activist Aaron Sorkin. item.title: Fact #531
item.description: Wesley Snipes’ 2001 thrift store drama Salvation was the first Hollywood film to raise awareness for the bargain hunter subculture. item.title: Fact #529
item.description: In an unaired prison interview with Guy Fieri, Wesley Snipes admitted that his karate belts were a fabrication of Woody Harrelson. However, he swore to Fieri and Fieri’s staff that he was a master of cliquot, a medieval Corsican self-defense style that required defenders to catapult themselves off s...

item.title: Fact #528
item.description: In an homage to Wesley Snipes, Leave the World Behind director Sam Esmail was said to have originally placed a CGI rendering of the deceased actor as Blade in the window of Danny the Contractor’s (Kevin Bacon) home, instead of Danny’s ten-year-old daughter.

item.title: Fact #527
item.description: In his Snipes memoir, Homunculus, Patton Oswalt writes that Wesley Snipes wasn’t only an expert at jimpenze, an obscure variation of Portuguese dirty thumb wrestling, but that he had possibly invented it.

item.title: Fact #526
item.description: Before arriving in Hollywood, Wesley Snipes was an amateur garbage collector. Even as his fame grew, Snipes remained true to waste management, calling it his first love and life’s true calling.

item.title: Fact #525
item.description: In the 1996 Uwe Boll film Bum Rollers, Wesley Snipes plays a down-at-heel Jamaican dwarf (Sadee) who entertains Wall Street brokers by allowing an unnamed 7-foot sidekick (“the Lug”) — played by Richard Kiel — to hurl him at unsuspecting NYC transit subway workers.

item.title: Fact #524
item.description: Wesley Snipes was a lifelong subscriber to Bushcraft Magazine, where he maintained a back-page advertisement soliciting urban python sightings.
